pullRequest.body:
Add a theorem showing that a periodic function is interval integrable over every interval if it is interval integrable
over one period. Add docstrings with section headings to improve readability. The theorem is used in [Project VD](https://github.com/kebekus/ProjectVD), which aims to formalize Value Distribution Theory for meromorphic functions on the complex plane.

---
<!-- The text above the `---` will become the commit message when your
PR is merged. Please leave a blank newline before the `---`, otherwise
GitHub will format the text above it as a title.

For details on the "pull request lifecycle" in mathlib, please see:
https://leanprover-community.github.io/contribute/index.html

In particular, note that most reviewers will only notice your PR
if it passes the continuous integration checks.
Please ask for help on https://leanprover.zulipchat.com if needed.

To indicate co-authors, include lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Co-authored-by: Author Name <author@email.com>

If you are moving or deleting declarations, please include these lines at the bottom of the commit message
(that is, before the `---`) using the following format:

Moves:
- Vector.* -> List.Vector.*
- ...

Deletions:
- Nat.bit1_add_bit1
- ...

Any other comments you want to keep out of the PR commit should go
below the `---`, and placed outside this HTML comment, or else they
will be invisible to reviewers.

If this PR depends on other PRs, please list them below this comment,
using the following format:
- [ ] depends on: #abc [optional extra text]
- [ ] depends on: #xyz [optional extra text]

-->

[![Open in Gitpod](https://gitpod.io/button/open-in-gitpod.svg)](https://gitpod.io/from-referrer/)

nodes.body:
### PR summary [545e7d7cd1](https://github.com/leanprover-community/mathlib4/pull/20938/commits/545e7d7cd1d1b60a27450f5f506c7918c4d1c100)

#### Import changes for modified files

No significant changes to the import graph


<details><summary>Import changes for all files</summary>

|Files|Import difference|
|-|-|

</details>

---

#### Declarations diff

`+ intervalIntegrable`
<details>
  <summary>You can run this locally as follows</summary>


```bash
## summary with just the declaration names:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh <optional_commit>

## more verbose report:
./scripts/declarations_diff.sh long <optional_commit>
```
</details>

The doc-module for `script/declarations_diff.sh` contains some details about this script.

---

<details><summary>No changes to technical debt.</summary>

You can run this locally as
```
./scripts/technical-debt-metrics.sh pr_summary
```
* The `relative` value is the weighted *sum* of the differences with weight given by the *inverse* of the current value of the statistic.
* The `absolute` value is the `relative` value divided by the total sum of the inverses of the current values (i.e. the weighted *average* of the differences).
</details>
@grunweg Thanks, as usual. I implemented all your suggestions, except the one with the positive/negative `T` where I am hesitant. I wrote a comment and would love to hear your opinion.
awaiting-author

@grunweg Weakening hypothesis of other lemmas. I shall be glad to do that, but let me confirm that I understand correctly what you have in mind.

I found six theorems with assumptions 
- `h_int : ‚àÄ t‚ÇÅ t‚ÇÇ, IntervalIntegrable g MeasureSpace.volume t‚ÇÅ t‚ÇÇ` and `hT : 0 < T`. 

In these theorems, the assumption `h_int` can be changed to 
- `h_int : ‚àÉ t, IntervalIntegrable f MeasureTheory.volume t (t + T)`

or alternatively

- `t : ‚Ñù`
- `h_int : IntervalIntegrable f MeasureTheory.volume t (t + T)`

Is that what you have in mind? If so, which of the two versions would you prefer? I am under the impression that the second might be easier to apply, but I might be mistaken‚Ä¶
@kebekus I think the second one is nicer to work with. I would make `t` implicit, as it can be inferred from the next hypothesis.
@grunweg Roger. I will work on this and come back to you. That might take a little time because my schedule is a bit tight over the next days.
Is there anything else you'd like to do? Otherwise, this looks good to me.
@grunweg Do I want to add anything else? I thought about that question, and eventually settled on a "no". Thanks again.

Then let's get this merged:
maintainer merge
üöÄ Pull request has been placed on the maintainer queue by grunweg.
I just took a cursory look: I only have some small comments.

Second round of nits: I have no further local comments.
I thought about the global picture for a bit: would you mind using this to strengthen a few lemmas below?
```suggestion

Do you need these calls? Otherwise, I'd tend to remove them.
```suggestion
The line is not needed for function, only for readability. I followed your suggestion.

As below: do you need this line? `this` in particular is being changed all the time
```suggestion
The line is not needed for function, only for readability. I followed your suggestion.
This can become `rw [Set.uIcc_subset_uIcc_iff_le]` (or perhaps the other direction), right?
Implemented following your suggestion.
Do you actually need `T` to be positive? (How do other theorems deal with this?)

I guess periodicity can be used formulated and used for negative `T`. However, it can not see a single theorem that does that. In this file alone, the assumption `(hT : 0 < T)` seems to appear 11 times.

My instinct is to leave the assumption as it is. If you disagree, I will weaken the hypothesis, but then I feel this should also be done for the other theorems -- which amounts to a massive refactor. Please advise.

Best -- Stefan.
Good point, thanks for checking. In this case, I'd go with what the other theorems do. (If another reviewer has strong opinions, we can always reconsider. I don't mind keeping it as-is.)
Personally, I tend to remove the blank lines before and after, in this case. Matter of taste, i.e. up to you.
Implemented.

Matter of taste
```suggestion
Thanks for adding these!
It's been my pleasure.
Do you need the arrows ‚Üë? I'd tend to omit them, if they don't change the statement.
Same below.
Removed arrows.

```suggestion
  obtain ‚ü®n‚ÇÅ, hn‚ÇÅ‚ü© := exists_nat_ge ((t - min a‚ÇÅ a‚ÇÇ) / T)

Your comments and code disagree: do you use natural numbers or integers? (I think "whichever is more convenient for this proof" is a good-enough answers, and am not sure if that's naturals or integers. Presumably, both get coerced to real numbers anyway.)
Corrected the comment, speaking about "natural numbers" now.
Can't you do `(a := a)` here (or remove the definition `a`)?
Shortened to `(a := a)`, which works indeed.
It turns out that even `(a := a)` is not needed.
Does `simp [‚Üê h‚ÇÅf.sub_int_mul_eq (k - n‚ÇÅ)]` work? If so, that's one line of code saved.
Yes, a minor variant of your suggestions works and saves one line.

I wondered if there's a shorter way to prove this, using `intervalIntegral_add_zsmul_eq`. The answer is "no, because that result requires interval integrability over any interval", right?

Though, can you use this to weaken the hypotheses of the lemmas below, please?

Correct me if I am wrong, but I do not see how `intervalIntegral_add_zsmul_eq` could apply easily here. Reason: Its conclusion is a statement about values of integrals, not about integrability. Am I overlooking something?

I will write below about the potential to weaken the hypothesis of the other lemmas.
Right, that's another reason.

pullRequest.title: feat: interval integrability of periodic functions
